physical_appearance:This is a Qing blue white censer whose form replicates that of a bronze gui censer. Painted around its neck is a panel of stylized motifs that visually echo taotie masks often found on ancient Chinese bronzes. The decoration around its body consists of ruyi-heads and ring handles.
subject_terms_1:porcelain paintings (visual works)  symbolism  freehand drawings (drawings)  ring handles zoomorphic

 Chinese Ming- Qing dynasties
 1368-1912 Blue and white ware China Ru yi (Scepters) China painting
subject_terms_3:visual arts  Decorative arts Ceramics  Religious life and practices
subject_terms_4:
sgcool_label_text:This vessel which takes the form of a bronze gui censer is painted with a band of stylised decoration around the neck
 and ruyi-heads and ring handles on the body. The decoration around the neck makes reference to taotie masks and other motifs used on ancient Chinese bronzes. The nod to antiquity highlights the prevalence of archaism as a key theme in the production of Chinese porcelain during the Qing dynasty (1644–1911).

The decoration around the neck makes reference to taotie masks and other motifs used on ancient Chinese bronzes. The nod to antiquity highlights the prevalence of archaism as a key theme in the production of Chinese porcelain during the Qing dynasty (1644–1911).
